title: Student Loans: What's Fair?
summary: The government leader Rachel Reeves says the student loan system is fair. Student loans are money students borrow for school and pay back later. She wants to keep the salary level where graduates start paying back the same for three years. This means if you earn more than £29,385, you will pay back your loan. A money expert named Martin Lewis disagrees. He says this is not fair because it treats loans like a tax, and it hurts people when prices go up. He thinks the government should change this rule. The loans are for students in England and Wales who started school between 2012 and 2023. They pay 9% of what they earn above the salary level. This issue is about balancing money for the government and helping graduates.

background_read: Student loans help people pay for college or university. After finishing school, graduates get jobs and earn money. They must pay back the loan based on how much they earn. The government sets rules for when and how much to pay. Sometimes, people argue about what is fair for everyone. This article talks about a debate between a government leader and a money expert over these rules.
Article_Structure: WHO: Rachel Reeves and Martin Lewis
WHAT: A debate about student loan repayment rules
WHY: To decide if freezing the salary level for repayments is fair

perspectives.description: Rachel Reeves thinks keeping the repayment threshold the same is fair to balance government spending.
Martin Lewis believes freezing the threshold is unfair and treats loans like a tax, hurting graduates.
